plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular evergreen shrub with glossy leaves and large, showy flowers that bloom in mid-winter to early spring. It thrives in temperate climates and is commonly cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value.
plants.location: Japan, China, southeastern United States, temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers are edible and sometimes used in teas, especially the related Camellia sinensis species which is the source of tea leaves.

plants.name: Erica carnea
plants.description: A low-growing evergreen shrub that blooms in late winter to early spring, producing bell-shaped flowers. It is well-suited to alpine and subalpine regions and ornamental rockeries.
plants.location: Central and southern Europe mountainous regions
plants.funFact: Winter heath can survive harsh winter conditions and often requires snow cover for protection.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A herbaceous perennial that blooms in mid-winter with large white flowers that sometimes have a pinkish tint. It grows naturally in the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe.
plants.location: Alps and other mountainous areas of Europe
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, Christmas Rose is not a true rose but a member of the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae). Its flowers can bloom through snow.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A coastal tree native to eastern Australia that produces cylindrical golden flower spikes. It blooms sporadically throughout the year, often including summer and winter months.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round, with peak flowering in summer and winter
plants.funFact: Banksia integrifolia is important for local wildlife, providing nectar for birds and mammals during times when few other flowers are available.
